Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Mentoring Consortium at the Nineteenth International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This grant supports student travel for select students participating in the Doctoral Mentoring Consortium (DMC) at the Seventeenth International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems (AAMAS 2020) will be held in Auckland, New Zealand, May 9-13, 2020.. This is the premier international conference for researchers in agents and multi-agent systems (MAS) across a fully international research community. This consortium is oriented on research and career development for students who have identified their PhD topics and are just embarking on that independent research. The central activities for the DMC include opportunities for students to present and discuss their work with their peers; interaction with an identified group of senior researchers for advice on Ph.D. research, a career panel to discuss career choices in industry and academia, small group activities led by assigned mentors, and a great deal of opportunity for interactions with the international research community in AAMAS, which might lead to future collaborative activity. In addition, the DMC includes a tutorial program with full-day and half-day tutorials that will provide detailed overviews of specific subfields by leading researchers in the field. <br/><br/>Sponsoring student travel to AAMAS conveys many benefits beyond the DMC program. The sponsored students have full access to a well-developed AAMAS workshop and conference program covering a diverse range of research areas in this community. This is an opportunity for students to engage in discussion with scientists from around the world and to explore new research directions and topics. AAMAS is the major international conference that will figure prominently in the research careers of students who remain involved in agents and MAS. Students gain valuable research insights from the exchange of technical ideas in this broader venue. In the process, they make valuable connections with potential collaborators from around the world. As intelligent software and embodies systems become more prevalent, it is clear that advances in intelligent agent technology will have significant impact in virtually any domain imaginable, including such national priorities as health and well-being, e-commerce, and national defense.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the participation of 86 US doctoral students in the premier International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS) and in the Doctoral Consortium (DC) held in conjunction with it. 30 students were supported in 2020 and 56 students was supported in 2021. Due to covid, AAMAS 2020 and 2021 were fully virtual conferences held May 9-13, 2020 and May 3-7, 2021.

All students were awarded registration participated in the DC in which they discussed their research with other student researchers and received feedback from a group of senior researchers. Students also attended the conference, which had a rich technical program complemented with an array of workshops, tutorials, and other events.

The 2020 DC included:

1)    A breakout session where each student briefly described their own research (i.e., elevator pitches).

2)    A breakout session where students brainstormed on how their work could help address challenges brought on by the pandemic.

3)    A career advice panel given by Sarit Kraus (Professor at Bar-Ilan University), Bo Li (a research assistant at Oxford), Nick Mattei (Assistant Professor at Tulane University) and Sven Koenig (Professor at USC).

4)    Mentor-mentee meetings

The 2021 DC included:

1)    Technical sessions in which students presented their work.

a.     An introduction session where each student briefly described their own research (i.e., elevator pitches).

b.     A more formal presentation session where each student presents their own research (i.e., 15-min presentations).

2)    A group breakout session where students formed groups and participated in a group ideation competition on how to address societal problems using their research.

3)    An invited talk on AI for Social Good was given by Milind Tambe (Professor at Harvard University).

4)    A career advice panel was given by Maria Gini (Professor at University of Minnesota), Tathagata Chakraborti (a researcher at IBM Research), Vincent Conitzer (Professor at Carnegie Mellon University), and Fei Fang (Assistant Professor at Carnegie Mellon University).

Out of the 86 students who received travel support, 25 of them are women.

Participation in the DC and the conference provided motivation for the students to continue in their research journey. It also helped them become members of the international community of scholars, by making personal connections with other researchers from around the world. In particular, due to the virtual conference and lower costs, we were able to fund a large number of students. As a result, we were able to greatly increase participation of students.

Scholarships were chosen on the basis of:

1) Match between their research topic and the topics covered in the DC;
2) Level of participation in the AAMAS conference;
3) Diversity of the participants;
5) Time to anticipated graduation
